Was shot on the 12th February, while attempting to cross the enemy's lines, Andrew Mahpe who was employed bringing goods from Baltimore for the benefit of the Confederacy.
He was formerly of Washington City.
This is founded upon certain facts by an eye witness.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Died in Charlottesville, on Saturday morning, February 14th, Mr. S. E. Sullivan, aged 58 years.

The subject of this notice was a man of high moral character — a man of true honor and Christian integrity.
He was known and respected as such in Charlottesville, in which place, he spent very many and the last years of his life.
The social circle in which he moved was very limited.
His enjoyment was found in his own family circle; and in the society of his faithful wife, a noble Christian woman he was satisfied.
God separated them but a short time.
Seven months ago his charming companion was taken away, and a fooling of deep loneliness came over his soul.
But, if beyond the cold stream, parted friends are reunited, that sense of loneliness has departed, and a loving husband and angel wife have met in that beautiful world where skies are ever bright, and hearts are ever happy, and separations are never known.--Let this reflection comfort those who feel their loss, and mourn the absence of true and faithful friends. "Raised are the dead who die in the Lord."
L A C.
Died, in Charlottesville, on Wednesday, February 4th, Josis Norris, son of Dr. Joseph Norris, in the 9th year of his age.

Little Josie was a dear, sweet boy. His nature was gentle, his disposition most amiable, and his little heart full of affection and love.
With a bright mind and smiling face, and beautiful black eyes that sparkled with intelligence and beamed with purest love Josie was sure to win your friendship and admiration.
But God wanted this little boy, and Jesus took him away before the storms of life had beaten upon his soul, or the trials and disappointments of earth had saddened his heart.
Yes, he is an angel now, and with a sainted mother and glorified brother who have gone before.
We miss thee, Josie, from the Sunday school, and from thy father's house, made so happy by thy presence; but thou art happier in Heaven and we bow down and rejoice in our sorrow. [*] L A C
At his residence, near Richmond, on Thursday evening, the 19th instant, in his 49th year, Ldwin Meeds, a native of Maryland, though for the past seventeen years a resident of this city.

He was a gentleman of liberal and extended views, and possessed great strength and energy of character.
Warm hearted and generous to a fault, his heart was over open to charity and distress, and it was never known of him to turn a deaf ear to want in any form.
He was an affectionate husband and a kind and indulgent father, and, being fully resigned to death, his family and friends may cherish the hope of a blissful reunion beyond the grave.

He will be buried from his residence to-day, at 12 o'clock M. The friends of the family are invited to attend.
Carriages will be in waiting at the Arlington House, on Main, between 6th and 7th streets, until 11 o'clock A. M.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 45, page 3.

div3.head: A trip Thorough the United States.
div3.p:
A gentleman who has recently visited several of the principal cities of the North has furnished us with an account of his trip and adjourn among the Yankees.
Leaving Richmond two days before Christmas, he arrived in Maryland on Christmas eve, and was warmly received in that portion of the State where he landed, where the Southern sentiment is almost unanimous.
Every facility was afforded him in making his way to Baltimore.
He arrived in that city in the middle of the day on Sunday, and, being well known there, found it necessary to observe great caution in his movements.
He remained in Baltimore one week, during which time he kept himself carefully secreted during the day, making his perambulations through the city after night by gas-light.
White he remained in the city he saw a number of its prominent business men, with whom he conversed freely.
They all seemed hopeful of the result of the present struggle, and believe that Southern independence will be the inevitable consequence of the present revolution.
There was no public expression of opinion, all parties appearing to be awed by and subdued on account of the presence and unwarrantable acts of the military stationed in their midst.
They express deep mortification at the present humiliated condition of their State, and great regret that the real sentiment of her people is not properly understand and her embarrassments appreciated.
The usual lively aspect of affairs in the city at this season of the year is painfully changed, and sadness and gloom hang over every thing.
Few ladies are to be seen on the street at any time.

From Baltimore our traveling friend made his way to the city of New York.
Here he remained for more than a week, and during that time circulated freely in all quarters, affording himself an opportunity of hearing expressions of opinion with reference to the present crisis from all classes of the population of the city.
None of the restraint felt in Baltimore is experienced in New York, and those who oppose the Lincoln Administration talk with great freedom and act independently, without apparent apprehension of consequences.
Of the war they declare themselves heartily tired, and with its management completely disgusted.
He heard Lincoln and his supporters openly denounced as traitors in the public houses in New York.
In favor of an honorable adjustment of the present difficulties there is a very strong and rapidly growing sentiment.
Little, if any hope is entertained of finally subjugating the South by the thinking portion of the community; but there is still a lingering hope that the States of the Confederacy may yet be induced to return to the Union.
It is everywhere openly and boldly proclaimed that no more troops can be raised for the prosecution of the war under present auspices.
The negro policy of the Republican Administration at Washington is violently condemned, and the bone and sinew, of whom Northern soldiers are made, swear they will fight neither for nor with the negro.
Gen. Lee is spoken of publicly as the greatest military genius of the age, and incomparably superior to any General upon the Federal side — Not only is he spoken of as a great commander, but as a polished gentleman, devoid of that braggadocio for which their own officers are characteristic. "Stonewall" Jackson is greatly admired for his during and brilliant achievements, and others of our general officers are talked of in terms of warm commendation.
The health of "Jeff Davis" is not unfrequently drank in the public bar-rooms During his sojourn in Gotham, our friend stopped at the St. Nicholas Hotel. General Wool and his staff were guests of the house at the same time. --There were very few soldiers in the city, and not many on the route between New York and Baltimore.
All the places of amusement in the city were open nightly, and pretty generally thronged.
Business was not active, many of the merchants declaring their determination to retain their goods on the shelf in preference to disposing of them for "green backs. " Very few "green backs" are in circulation, the principal currency being State bank money, and postage currency for small change.
No specie is seen or circulated.

Leaving New York the gentleman alluded to proceeded to Boston, where he arrived in the midst of a heavy snow storm.
Being on a sight-seeing expedition he determined, however, not to be deterred by the inclement weather.
Procuring a hack, he visited Charleston, Cambridge, and the Bunker Hill Monument.
He does not recollect to have heard a word said about the war during his stay in Boston, and the people there seem scarcely conscious of the stupendous struggle that is in progress.
There seemed to be a general spirit of gayety, the Yankees in that locality apparently feeling little of the pressure resulting from the troubles which are afflicting other and more deserving sections of the country.
He soon tired of the city, and left it in disgust, returning to New York by the "Stonington route," where he remained several days longer.

From thence he came on to Philadelphia, and put up at the Girard House, intending to spend several days in that city.
On the night of his arrival Senator Wall, of New Jersey, who was en route for Washington, addressed a large gathering of the people from the front balcony of the Girard House.
Our friend says that no idea can be formed from the newspaper reports of the enthusiasm created by this speech.
From beginning to ending it was received with tumultuous applause by the Philadelphians.
After the speech was concluded, our traveler, in passing through the hall of the hotel, met with a detective whom he had formerly known in Baltimore, and by whom he was afraid of being recognized.
This unexpected meeting of an old acquaintance — with whom he had no desire to hold an interview — determined him to make his sojourn in the Quaker city very brief, and as the cars were about departing southward, he at once engaged passage.

After more than a week of tedious journeying, over a route which we do not deem it entirely prudent to mention, he arrived safely in Richmond much gratified with his trip, and firmly impressed with the belief, from all that he could see and hear, that the first of July will witness the termination of the war.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of valuable real and personal property at auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at public auction.
Tuesday, the 10th of March next, on the premises, the farm of Povail Turner, dec'd, (known as Pitts's,) on the Chickahominy river, in the county of New Kent, three miles from Summit Depot, on the York River Railroad and twenty miles from Richmond, containing 693 acres, of which about 400 are in a high state of cultivation, well enclosed, and adapted to the growth of corn, wheat, and oats, with 125 bushels of winter oats and 24 bushels of wheat needed, and a portion me and set in clover, with a dwelling-house and all other necessary out-houses, and a well of excellent water in the yard.
The balance of the land is in original growth of pine, oak, maple, and cypress.
Also, the Farming Utensils, of valuable Mules, Horse, Oxen, Cows, Sheep, and Hogs.
Also, Buggies, Carriages, Certs, Wagons, Corn, Oats, Foder, Hay, Shucks, and Straw; Household and Kitchen Furniture, Bacon Lord, and Poultry.

Also, at the same time and place, a Tract of Land detached from and within a quarter of a mile of the farm, containing 80 acres, well enclosed with a plank fence, one half in cultivation, with valuable low grounds, and well adapted for a pasturage.
Also, 50 acres lying on the York River Railroad, fifteen miles from Richmond, which has on it a dwelling-house, and some wood and timber standing on it.
Also, a first-class Steam Saw Mill and fixtures, of twenty four horse power, in good repair.
Terms--For the real estate, made known on the day of sale; cash will be required for the perishable property.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the deep-run Turnpike, at auction.
div3.p:
--As administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A M, the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shepherd.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the chillest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd,
Sale by J M Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Pord, who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J A Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Beautiful improved farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or fifteen Negroes, for Sale
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for mile, at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, she 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day,) a beautiful estates, known as Meadow Creek, containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia, has an abundances of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, of a high degree of improvement, has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well set in old grass yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out-houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that an desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely Negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

lg.head: By J. E. W.
lg.l: winds of Autumn, why blow Ye now?
Ye can no longer have
the brow of her we loved so well,
but only reach her grave.
death's wind has been before you,
though not Wareing had it given,
and Waffle a building spirit
to above — in reason.
leaves Autumn, why fail Ye now?
the earth.
which now doth bide those gentle eyes
when beheld your ebbing mirth?
the cold, cold clay 's before you,
and heavily creams the breast
upon which in your straggling fail
you often chanced to rest.
rain of Autumn, why come you now?
Seek you to vic with tears
Shed upon that billowed spot,
made sacred by our prayers?
away, 'tis not your place--
Blew here play your part;
the raise of Hearth but cold appear,
with the waters of the heart.
A'arl poor friend, what now are winds to you,
Or winter's snow or summer's scanted dew?
What the blooming rose, or autumn's falling leaf,
Or this my lonely wall of grief?
Thou art in the land of soils, beyond the cable shore,
To which for thee my prayers ascend, ever more.
Praying that when this poor form lies beneath the of,
The soul may find eternal rest with thee and with thy God.

div3.head: Fidelity of a Doe.
div3.p: --Numerous instances of the attachment and fidelity of the dog have been put on record from time to time, and the army correspondent or the Philadelphia Inquirer relates the following proof as witnessed on the bloody field near Fredericksburg:

As Son John Covode, in company with a number of officers was passing over the battle-field beyond Fredericksburg, their attention was called to a small dog lying by a corpse.
Mr. Covode halted a few minutes to fee if life was extinct.
Raising the coat from the man's face, he found him deed.
The dog, looking wishfully up, ran to the dead man's face and kissed his silent lips.
Such succession in a small dog was so singular that Mr. Covode examined some papers upon the body, and found it to be that of Sergeant W. H. Brown company C 9 at Pennsylva is. The dog was shivering with the cold, but refused to leave his master's body, and as the coat was thrown over his face again he seemed very uneasy, and tried to get under it to the man's face.
He had, it seems, followed the regiment into battle and stuck to his master and when he fell remained with him, refusing to leave him or eat anything.
As the party returned, an ambulance was carrying the corpse to a little grove of trees for interment, and the little dog following the only mourner at that funeral as the hero's comrades had been called to some other point.

For a reliable man, over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply as the office of

For such an one's liberal price will be paid.

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars reward
div3.p: --The following Negroes, ranaway from the Carbon Hill Elmes, in this county, on the 16th inst. vtz:

Hatry Williams, a dark-brown negro, 5 feet 9½ inches in heigh, not very stout, good looking about 32 years old, various veiw in both legs, left leg on affected lately purchased from Green county, N C.

Ben Williams, dark brown 5 feet 6 inches high, very short, round face, very likely, about 25 years old, just recovered from a serious attack of per months, lately purchased from Jones & Slatery and came from Green county N. C.

Jim Lawrence, a black negro, 5 feet 3 inches in bright, remarkably bread as on the shouldiers, and powerfully made, about 30 or 32 years old, good teeth, counterance shrew down and rasonlity a short mark in the right leg, lately purchased, and came from near Goldsborough, N. C.

George Holt, a brown negro, 5 feet 8 inches high about 15 years old, good teeth eyes rather close together, nor stout, has a rear from a severe wound inside of his left hand, was a fireman on one of the North Carolina railroads for four years, comes from Goldsborough N. C.

Evall Grisfin, (or Rilas) a light brown negro, 5 feet 7 inches in height, round shoulders, heavy brown, slim figure and indifferent looking, was under medical treatment when he left for a chronic disease is about 32 years old, came from near Goldsborough, N. C.

Jim is no doubt the leader of the party, and is probably endeavoring to reach the Yankee lines near Goldsborough.
They carried an axe with them.

For the apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond of either of these negroes I wall pay $10 if taken in this city or county; $20 if taken in an adjoining county; or $20 if taken up thirty miles from Richmond in any direction.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--A young negro man, named John Chisman, who came to Richmond from Williamsburg some time last spring, and who has been hired about the city until recently, has disappeared.
Fifty dollars reward will be paid by Messrs Blair & Chamberlayne, on Main street, if the negro shall be delivered to them or secured in jail in Richmond to their order.
The man is about 12 years old, black, about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches tall, and quite likely.
Mr. Farkes Slater, south side of Broad street, between 4th and 5th, can give information as to the acquaintance of the man amongst his own color, &c.

closer.signed: Robt A bright, C S A.

div3.p:
I will pay a liberal reward for the arrest and delivery to me of confinement in come jail so that I may get him, of my man Stokes, who left my house, in Amelia county, on the 18th of January, and is evidently attempting to make his escape to the Yankee's or has hired himself to work in some camp.
Stokes it about 23 years of age, 5 feet 6 or 8 inches high, black complexion, and has a large scar on his side, by a burn.
div3.closer:
Mary A Hafdaway.
Deatonville P O Amelia co. fe 16--6t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Shayed or stolen from my boat, at the corner of Byrd and 6th ats, on the night of the 9th inst., a dark iron gray Horse, about 4 years old, with a black, short mane, and light (fiaxer) tall at the end. He has a scar a ross his forehead about two inches long and also a scar on the inside of one of his hind legs, which has nearly healed up. He has quite a large neck, and also large leg and small body.
I will pay $50 reward for his return to McCarthy & Young's corner of 6th and Byrd sts.

div3.head: Forty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
-- my farm near Keysville, in co Va, on Sunday, the 5th instant, my negro man George Brakton.
I bought him of Dickinson, Hill & Co, as the property of 5 his A. Lacy, New Kent co, Va. in December last.
His wife lives near Mr. Lucy's, where, I suppose, he is making his way. He is a little under the medium height black, has fall whickers, speaks rather indistinctly; had on when he left a Yankee blue over goat and vest, black hat and patched pants.
He is about 35 years old. I will give $30 reward for him if taken between my house and Richmond, and brought to my house, or $29 if taken in Richmond or beyond that place, and lodged in jail in Richmond so that I get him again

div3.head: Twenty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the return of a small negro boy named Peter, or for any information given so that I can get him. He left my house on Union Hill about the 25th of January.
It is very likely he may report himself free, and apply to some of the hospitals or camps around Richmond for employment.
He has a scar under his chin from scrofula, and one also over one eye and is about 14 years of age.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I am informed that my man, John who sometimes calls himself Jno Baker, or Jno Ligon, at others calls himself Joe, was taken up recently from the army near Fredericksburg, where he was employed as a cook, and sent to some of the public or private jails in the city of Richmond.
Any information furnished me in the county of Powhatan, Jefferson Post Office, or to me at the American Hotel No. 44, until Friday at 12 o'clock, will be liberally reward.
John is 23 years old, about 5 feet 2 or 3 inches high, black, has a scar on his right or left arm occasioned by a burn.
He left my residence in July last, and I presume he has been with the army until he was apprehended.
The information I have leads a most to a certainty that he is now in the city of Richmond in jail.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Friday, January 16, 1863, a negro man named Griffin.
The said slave is about 23 years of age; dark brown skin; five feet four or six inches high, and his left arm smaller than his right, having been broken when young.
Griffin was formerly owned by Rob Lowe, of Chapel Hill N C, who sold him to J Monroe Carter, of Richmond Va, on the 5th of October 1862.
I will give the above reward for the capture and return to me of said slave, or for his confinement in jail, so that I get him again.
div3.closer:
H D Dickinson Rice's Depot,
Prince Edward co, Va fe 13--3t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Absconnes from my farm near Ashland, Hanover county, about the 15th of December last, my man Jor, about 28 or 30 years of age black complexion, 5 feet 6 or 7 inches high.
He was purchased by me in Richmond last fall, and formerly belonged to Wm Woodfin Cun Borland county, about whose place he is supposed to be in king.
I will pay the above reward if delivered to C W Coleman, near Ashland, or lodged in some jail so I get him again.
div3.closer:
W A Dick,
Ashland, Hanover county, February 13, 1863, fe 14--2taw4w*

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Wylliesburg, in Charlotte county, during the month of June, 1862 my man Bartlett.
For his apprehension and delivery to me, if taken up out of the State, I will pay the above reward; if captured within the State, and placed in jail so that I can get him, I will pay $50 Bartlett is about 20 years of age, of small stature, weighing, perhaps, 130 pounds; 5 feet 5 inches high mahogany color, one upper tooth out in front, low forehead, and dull countenance.
When last seen he was in the vicinity of Clarksville.

div3.head: Seventy-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I offered for the apprehension and delivery of my slave William Henry, who disappeared from the fortifications around Richmond about the 10th of December.
Said slave is about 19 years of age 5 feet high, thick act, thick of speech, gruff in manner of speaking, and generally clears his throat before beginning; has a peculiarly formed head, protuberance on the bank of it, and eyes somewhat popped.
The above reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery of said slave to me it Danville, or lodged in the jail in Richmond so that I get him in possession.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--$100 reward.--Ran away from "Wakefield," the farm in Hanover next to joining Mr. Geo W Doowell's, on Monday, the 9th instants, a negro man named Jim. Said negro is of dark complexion, 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high, about 23 years old, and has a defect in his right eye. He was crossed in gray clothes, and had on either boots or wooden bottomed yellow shoes.
Before leaving he spoke of going to the Junction to get with our army, and I especially request quartermasters and wagon masters on the lines of the Central of Fredericksburg Railroads to keep a look-out for him. I will pay the above reward for his apprehension and delivery in the jail at Hanover Court House, so that I get him against or to myself in Richmond.

closer.signed: Ex'r of Mrs. Judith Smith, dec'd.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward
div3.p: --Ran away from the subscriber, on the 12th last., a bright mulatto Girl, sixteen years old, named Bes. She is supposed to be about the city, I will give the above reward for her arrest and return to me, or nor filament in jail, so that I get her.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Ranaway about the 15th of February, a black man named Mices, about 23 years old. He was purchased of W H Pleasants, on the 10th instant.
I will pay the above reward for his delivery to Messrs Hill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: Runaway in jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of Henrico county, as a runaway, a negro boy named Jim as the property of John Montgomery, of the county of York, Va. The said boy is about 16 years old, 5 feet 7 inches high, with brown skin; had on when committed a full salt of gray Virginia clothing.
The owner of said boy is requested to come forward, prove property, pay Sargon, and take him away, or he will be dealt with as the law directed.

closer.signed: Geo D Pleasants S H C.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Ran away from the subscriber on the 1st day of February, a dark brown skin, negro man 6 feet high, named Peter, about 23 years old. I will give the above reward to any person who will bring him to me, or have him confined in any jail in the State that I may get him. He has a wife in Powhatan county, and was recently bought in Scotland county, Va.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--$25 reward.--Ran off from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on the 27th inst, a black Girl, about 16 years old and very good teeth in front.
She was purchased of Mrs. Mary W Coloman, of Carolina county, and may be making her way back, I will pay $25 for her arrest and delivery to Hill, Richmond & Co.

div3.head: Important to conscripts.
div3.p:
--The undersigned having been detailed for a short time on respectfully announce, by authority vested in me by order of Major-General G W Smith, the partial suspension of the conscript law, so as to permit conscript to volunteer in the companies of their own selection in this command, without passing through camps of instruction, and receive the county and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.
I urge upon the people of this city the importance of speedily filling up the ranks of our army, in order that the threatened invasion of the State may be repelled.

It is confidently hoped that with the liberal inducements I am authorized to tender to conscripts, a large number will be added to the rolls, and ample means thereby secured for the common defence.
A candid and earnest appeal will be sufficient, it is believed to awaken you to this high duty which you own to yourselves and to your country.
I can be found at any time between the hours of 10 A M and 9 P M in the Military Hall, above the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main streets.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --In accordance with Special Orders, No. 32, from the Adjutant and Inspecting General's Office, I am new in Powhatan on recruiting service, and announce the partial suspension of the Conscript law, so as to permit conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection, without passing through camps of instruction, and to receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.

It is useless for me to make an appeal to your patriotism.
The desolate condition of the fairest portion of your State speaks in strongly terms than anything I could say. Come forward, then, one and all, and volunteer at once, that the vile invader may be swept from the sacred soil of your native State.
Any one within the conscript age who will come forward and volunteer will have the privilege of attaching himself to any company be may select, and will be furnished with transportation to the company on application to me. He will also receive $30 bounty and all other benefits provided by law in such cases.

div3.head: Five hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Deserted from comply on 26th Virginia reg't, on the 1st inst, Henry Scott, an Irishman about 47 years old about 5 feet 6½ inches high; dark-brown or black hair; eyes; dark complexion; has a ship tai toned on his blest, a woman on each arm, the woman on the left arm has a child in her arms; has a scar on the back of the left hand, and her lost a portion of the middle finger of the right band.--Henry Scott was mustered as a substitute for Robt Edmundson, of Halifax co, Va. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me at the camp of the 26th Virginia regiment, Wise's brigade, near Chaffa's Bruff.
div3.closer:
John T Perrin, Capt Co B.
25th Virginia regiment. fe 20--11t*

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
--On or about the 20th of June last John Forine, a member of Comp'y 18th Georgia reg't. He was enlisted at Richmond on the 15th of October, 1864, has dark eyes; black hair; is about 5 feet 11 inches high, and is supposed to be in Powhatan county.
A reward of $30 will be paid for his arrest and delivery to some proper officer.
div3.closer:
John F Hardin, Lt com'g Co F,
18th Georgia regiment. fe 19--4t*

div3.head: Eight hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --A reward of $200 each is offered for the following named privates of company F, 19th Va regiment:

James Gaffney, a short, stout man, sandy hair and beard, blue eyes about 35 years old; enlisted as a substitute near Richmond, about August 6, 1852, called himself a Kentuckian, and had a discharge from the 1st Kentucky regiment.
John Hogan, a short, stout Irishman, black hair and eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high looks about 30 years old; will be found near Richmond enlisted as a substitute in December, 1862.
Martin Kelley, about 5 feet 10 inches high very dark complexion, dark hair, this dark beard supposed to have enlisted in the 4th Virginia cavalry.
Richard Mattnews, an Irishman; sandy hair and beard, about 5 feet 9 inches high.
div3.closer:
Bennett Taylor, Capt Co F,
19th Va regt. fe 32--3t*

div3.head:
Camp near Port Royal,
January 30, 1863.
div3.p: Arrest the Digneters — The usual reward of $30 will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me, or to the officer, in command of Castle Thunder, Richmond city, of the following deserters from Company "A," 8th Regiment Louisiana Volunteers:

list.item:
1. Private Jas Boyd, a native of Ireland, about 32 years of age, red hair and beard ruddy complexion, marked by the small pox, somewhat over 5 feet in height, and a teamster by occupation.
He is supposed to have joined a Virginia cavalry company.
2. Private Jno H Cummins, a native of New York State, 21 years old, light hair, no beard, fall complexion, blue eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high, and a painter by trade.
3. Private Patrick Donohue, a native of Ireland, about 37 years old, light black hair, ruddy complexion, quick of speech and motion, about 5 feet 6½ inches high, and a gardener by trade.
4. Private Patrick Fitzgerald, a native of Ireland, near 40 years of age, black hair and beard slightly bale, black eyes, about 5 feet 6 or 5 inches high, and a day laborer.

5. Private Wm Reagan a native of New York State 30 years old, auburn hair, hazel eyes, stout built, some 5 feet 7 inches high, and a blacksmith by trade.
He deserted in the early part of last June, and is supposed to be in Richmond city, and lately received a notice from Capt West, one of the Quartermasters of that city, that he had paid him $174,58 as pay, bounty, and clothing money.

div3.p: I will add $20 for Reagan's arrest, thus making the reward in his case $50

closer.signed: Capt co A, St Reg La Vols.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Co "E"59th Reg Va Vols,
Manchester, Feb. 10th, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted.--The following named men are deserters from my company, now stationed in Manchester.
It they will come and report to me at once, they will only lose their pay; but if brought back under arrest, will be court-martialed and dealt with as the court may direct:
Geo Matin, of Brunswick co;
Wm Chapman, a substitute;
Henry Donanoe, a substitute;
John Henry, a substitute;
J T Slites, a substitute from Pittaylvania
W C Moore, Powhatan;
R G Birdsong, Dinwiddie.
I will give $30 reward for the delivery of each of the above named men to me, in Manchester, on if put in Castle Thunder in Richmond, so that I can get them.
div3.closer:
F. S. Mosey, Capt.
Co I. 59th Reg't Va Vols. fe 11--2aw2w*

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be paid for the apprehension of any one of the following named Deserter, from the Alexandria Light Artillery--camp near Richmond:
Jno Robertson: Gray eyes, dark hair, florid complexion, 5 feet 10½ inches high, aged 45 years, born in Ireland.
Timothy Nagan: Light eyes, brown hair, florid complexion, 5 feet high, born in Ireland, aged 45 years.
Thomas Conner: Blue eyes, light hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high, born in Ireland, aged 45 years.
Jno Davis: Hazel eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 9½ inches high, born in England.
Chas Heslin: Blue eyes, black hair with a sprinkling of gray, dark complexion, 5 feet 11 inches high, born in Ireland, aged 45 years.

div3.head:
Camp Md Va battalion,
Fields's brigade, a P Hill's division,
February 5th, 1863,
div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward.--A reward of $30 each will be paid for the arrest and the delivery to me of any one of the following names deserters:
Stepfano Gouovick, an Italian, with very dark complexion, black eyes and hair, and about 5 feet 8 inches high; age, 12 years.
Augustus Kaisee, a German, with light complexion, blue eyes and light hair, about 5 feet 10 inches high, and 22 years of age.

J N Phelphs, halls from Lynchburg, says Kentuckian by birth, and was employed on the James River and Kanawha Canal for some time previous to enlistment; complexion dark, dark eye and hair, 6 feet high, and about 24 years of age.

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at Marine Camp, Drewry's Bluff, of Wm Meens, a deserter from the C S Marine Corps.
He is 23 years of age, 5 feet 8½ inches high, blue eyes, light hair, fair complexion.
He had been wounded in the left and supposed in escaping from Camp Lee, where he had engaged himself as a substitute.
div3.closer:
A S Taylor,
Major and Q M C R M C,
Office 115 Broad st. fe 12--5t

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted, on the march from Culpeper to Fredericksburg, Va, on or about the 20th of Nov'r W P Brown, a substitute in Co V, 41st Virginia reg't. Said Brown professes to be a Gana' lan by birth.
He is about 21 years of age; 5 feet 8 inches high; of delicate appearance; dark complexion, and dark hair.
He formerly resided in Richmond.
A reward of $100 will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of the above deserter.
div3.closer:
A H Portlook, Capt Co F,
41st Va reg't, camp near Fredericksburg, Va. fe 2--3t*

div3.head: Notice to conscripts
div3.p: --The Medical Examining Board for the 3d Congressional District is now holding its cession at the Camp of Instruction, near Richmond.
All persons of conscript age, who have been authorized to appear before this Board for final examination, will report immediately.
div3.closer:
John A Coke, Capt and Reroll'g Officer

Balaam, Dr. Murphy, (Florida Hospital,) came in Nov, 30th, 1862.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:

He must be qualified to teach Latin, French, and Ms homstick, as well as the venal English branches.
Terms, not less than 103 per session, of ten months and pro rate for a shorter time.
Address, immediately, giving reference.

J T Goodwin,
Bowling Green, Carolina co Va. fe 13--4t*

To one that will a good price will be paid.
Inquire of

A Marylander preferred.
Address "J M K," City Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A situation as Teacher in a private family, in the city of Richmond of the immediate vicinity, by a Virginia lady, competent to teach a full course of English, and thoroughly qualified to teach Music on the Plane.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: ----A Steam Saw Mills.--I am desirous of purchasing a Ports his Steam Saw Mill, of from 15 to 30 horse power. Any one having such in good order, and in a locality from which same may be conveniently transported to Richmond, will find a purchaser by addressing, stating price and particulars,

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Nails.--Wanted, 2,500 kegs of Nails, assorted Partice wishing to nail (in lots of not less than 50 kegs,) will specify the quantity, sizes, points of delivery and price.--Address

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --To hire for the balance of the year, a good Gardener.
div3.closer:
Thomas Johnston,
Of West &Johnston, 106 Main st. fe 12--3t

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Store Room in the central part of the city, for which an enormous price will be given.
By applying at once to

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Blacksmiths.--Wanted two No. 1 Horseshoes, for which I will pay the highest price.
Also, a good Helphs, white or colored.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Samuel A. Ceath.
Manchester, Feb, 15th 1863 fe 12--3t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A gentleman wished to rant a comfortably furnished Room with or without board, for himself and with in a respectable private family.
A liberal price will be paid.
Inquire at the office of
div3.closer:
Mahorey & Mogne,
Dentists 21st Main st. fe 7--3t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--At the Carbon Hill Mines, in this county, an active, intelligent man, accustomed to the charge of steam engines, and experienced in the management of negroes.
Written applications with reference only will be attended to.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A quick, active, intelligent Youth--one whose parents reside in the city preferred.
Apply at once to

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Moore, either furnished or unfurnished; or two rooms, in a central portion of the city, for a small family.
Address "A E," Dispatch office

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Negroes — We still wish to hire able-bodied negro men and Boys to work at our blast furnaces in Rockbridge and Sotetourt counties, and at our goal since near this city. --Those having hands on the fort foliations whole terms of service will soon expire, can procure good homes for them by early application to us
div3.closer:
J E Anderson & Co.
Tredeger Iron Works. fe 16--1w

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--an Overseas.--The advertiser desires to employ, immediately, an Overseas to take charge of a farm in Henrico county.
He must be well recommended for sobriety and qualifications.
A married man, with a small family, preferred.
Apply to
div3.closer:
A D Williams, 11th street,
Bet Main and Bank sts. fe 16--3t

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--old Axes — old Axes.--wish to purchase my quantity of old Axes, for which the highest press will be paid.
Also, 10,000 pounds of old Beans.
Apply immediately.
div3.closer:
W F Jenkins,
In Cary Alley, near corner of
14th and Cary sts. fe 16--6t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Weavers.--Woman Wavers can get employment at the mills of the Manchester Cotton and Wool Manu acquiring Company, at full rates of wages.
Apply at the Factory.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--to Buy — For a Nurse, a middle aged family Servant, next to habits and of good disposition.
Apply at No. 111 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Carpenters — We wish to have two negro Carpenters by the year.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A steady white man, to work on a farm.
Apply a 183 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Teacher, to instruct two children in English, Latin and French.
Liberal arrangements will be made with a competent party, either male or female.
Address "J. S.," Dispatch Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --$2,000 will be paid for a furnished House, with six or more rooms in it. Address

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Warehouse located on Main Cary, or one of the cross streets, between 9th and 14th streets.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A good Cook, Washer and Ironer, for a small family.
Apply to "W," at

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Three and competent gentlemen, who desire commissions to the army, to recruit a company of Mounted Royoearn or cavalry, under authority from the Secretary of War.
Address "Captain," Box No. 1181,city Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Marble Cutines.--We wish to employ a good Letteree in Marble a steady hand can get a good job. Apply in person as soon as possible to
div3.closer:
Marquis & Kelly,
Staunace Va. fe 12--6t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--One or two unfurnished rooms with use of kitchen, between 1st and 19th streets, and between Cary and Clay.
Part or whole of a small house preferred.
Address

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A Grinder.--Wanted, at the C S Armory, fact of 9th street and canal, a drat rate Grinder.
One who has been occasioned to gun work preferred.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Marries.--$50 county, and pass from $15 to $25 per month.
By law one subject to enrollment and conscripts, at any time before being mustered into a company or recent, may enlist in the marine corps for the for three years, at their option.
Good clothing and subsistence furnished by Government.
Apply at the office on 9th, between Main and Cary sts.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--200 Teamsters, for which $20 per will be paid and and nothing furnished, or per month and ration.
These Teamsters, are for the Yorage and not reliable to transfer as some other of the Government service.
Apply to Hanover Court- House, or Ke, 67 Main street,
